p: In a previous study with six S. canadensis populations (three invasive populations from China and three native populations from America) and one K. striata population (from the area invaded by S. canadensis in China), we determined that the enhanced competitive ability of S. canadensis relative to K. striata in China resulted from increased root exudates [11]. Because neither biomass nor height of S. canadensis in our previous study was significantly affected by the source of the S. canadensis population (either from the original or invaded lands), the current study used one invasive S. canadensis population originating from the invaded area in China. One native K. striata population from China was also used. Seeds of S. canadensis and K. striata were collected in the same locations (30°16′N, 120°11′E) in Hangzhou, Zhejiang province (China), where the area was invaded by S. canadensis. Seeds of S. canadensis and K. striata were air-dried and stored at 4°C.
